title: SB 1.18.20 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 10-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 20th verse of the 18th chapter of the first canto of Shri Madbhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the specific verse from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed.

segments.key_quote: So this verse is a very important verse spoken by Suta Goswami.
segments.summary: The speaker recites and translates verse 20 from the 18th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, highlighting the unlimited nature of God and the unique position of Lakshmi Devi.

segments.key_quote: Only one personality in the entire cosmic manifestation that is the supreme personality of Godhead, Krishna alone is unlimited.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the unlimited nature of Krishna, stating that He is the only unlimited personality in the cosmic manifestation and that His qualities, forms, and opulences are also unlimited.

segments.key_quote: So he accepts the service of Lakshmi Devi he accepts the service of his innumerable devotees pure devotees simply for blessing them for giving them his blessings for showing his mercy upon them.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that while demigods seek the favor of Lakshmi Devi, she serves Krishna, who is complete and doesn't need her service, but accepts it to bless His devotees.

segments.key_quote: Shruti is the original Vedas which have been received in oral translation.
segments.summary: The speaker begins to explain the difference between Shruti and Smriti literature, defining Shruti as the original Vedas received through oral tradition.

segments.key_quote: Shruti literature is the compilation of the same vedic message by the saintly persons by the great devotees by witches sages or by dead火根 for explaining the Vedic message to a particular audience to explain in an easily understandable way
segments.summary: The speaker defines Smriti literature as compilations of Vedic messages by saintly persons, making the knowledge more accessible, and gives examples like Puranas and Itihasas.

segments.key_quote: The personality of Godhead or the Parameshwara Parabrahman according to the Shrutis has nothing to do so in the Shrutis it is said natasya karyam karanam cha vidyate natat samascha abhyadikas cha dhrushyate parashya
segments.summary: The speaker quotes Shruti literature to emphasize that the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Parameshwara Parabrahman, has nothing to do, meaning He is independent and self-sufficient.

segments.key_quote: His position is unique in that he has unlimited potencies and Is every action is carried out systematically in his natural perfect ways
segments.summary: The speaker reinforces the idea that Krishna has no equal or superior and is full in Himself, unlike beings in the material world who are always in need, concluding the lecture.
